metadata.case_name: Jahangiri Mal Kalu Ram (Appellants) v. Official Receiver and Others

facts.text: Appellants are two brothers and their sons who constituted a firm called Jahangiri Mal Kalu Ram.
On 19-11-1956, appellants were declared insolvents and Official Receiver took possession of all their properties including the building in dispute.
On 21-11-1956, appellants filed objection petition under s.60 CPC read with s.4 Provincial Insolvency Act claiming exemption for the building under clause (ccc).
Official Receiver contended that the property is not a residential house but a shop, and back portion (kitchen, raised platform) given in trust for residential purposes.
Creditors contended that property is a shop, though appellants using back portion as residence.

Trial Court (Insolvency Judge) held building consists of two distinct units: front shop (main hall, two apartments, kotha integral part), back residential (BCDE and upper storey). Upheld objection for residential portion, dismissed for shop.
Appeal by insolvents: District Judge Hissar held no doubt building is main residential house of insolvents, allowed appeal.
Appeal by creditors: Single Judge accepted shop has separate access but connected to residential portion; only portion of ground floor used as shop; upheld District Judge.

Letters Patent Appeal (judgment dated April 7, 1966): Division Bench followed Full Bench Ude Bhan v. Kapoor Chand, held if portion let out, whole house not occupied by judgment-debtor; allowed appeal, restored Insolvency Judge order.
Building is single one: portion downstairs opens on chowk Mandi Dabwali and public street used as shop; no evidence upstairs used for shop.

legal_issues.text: Interpretation of clause (ccc) to proviso to sub-s.(1) of s.60 CPC: whether main residential house occupied by judgment-debtor (non-agriculturist) is exempt from attachment if a portion is used by him as a shop.

petitioner_arguments.text: Building in dispute is main residential house entitled to exemption under clause (ccc) of s.60(1) CPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.60 CPC proviso clause (ccc); s.4 Provincial Insolvency Act

respondent_arguments.text: Property is a shop, not residential house; back portion used for residence but front is distinct shop.
Portion used as shop analogous to letting out to tenant, hence not occupied by judgment-debtor, no exemption for whole house (following Ude Bhan Full Bench).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ude Bhan Ors. v. Kapoor Chand Ors.

court_reasoning.text: Building is single main residential house occupied by insolvents; no warrant for finding two distinct portions; Division Bench accepted this but wrongly analogized to letting out.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Shop portion has separate access but connected to residential; upstairs entirely residential.

court_reasoning.text: Full Bench Ude Bhan applies to portion let out to tenant (not occupied by judgment-debtor), not to portion used by owner as shop.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Using portion of residential house for business does not cease it being residential house, given social conditions in country.

court_reasoning.text: Composite user common: lawyer's office, doctor's consulting room in house remain part of residential house.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Punjab cases from 1951 support: shop on ground floor does not convert building to non-residential if occupied by owner.

holdings.text: Main residential house occupied by judgment-debtor exempt under clause (ccc) even if portion used by him as shop; whole building exempt from attachment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ude Bhan Ors. v. Kapoor Chand Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Applies to portion let out to tenant (not occupied by judgment-debtor); does not cover owner using portion as shop.

precedents_cited.case_name: Agha Jafar Ali Khan v. Radha Kishan
precedents_cited.relevance: Shop on ground floor does not convert whole building to non-residential if used by owner for residence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Firm Ganga Ram v. Firm Jai Ram
precedents_cited.relevance: Ground floor commercial, upper floors residential: entire house exempt if main residential house occupied by judgment-debtor; recognizes composite user in country.

precedents_cited.case_name: Punjab Mercantile Bank Limited in liquidation Jullundur City v. Messrs General Typewriter Co., Jullundur City
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguishes letting out (chabaras to tenants not exempt) from owner use; portion let out not occupied by judgment-debtor.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Exempts main residential house and appurtenant land of non-agriculturist judgment-debtor occupied by him, unless specifically charged; added by Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act 7 of 1934, amended by Acts 12 of 1940, 6 of 1942.

statutes_cited.name: Provincial Insolvency Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for objection petition read with s.60 CPC.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment of Division Bench set aside; judgments of Single Judge and District Judge restored; whole building held exempt from attachment as main residential house occupied by insolvents.
outcome.relief_granted: Exemption of entire building from attachment and sale.

key_quotes.text: "In the circumstances and social conditions of this country it would be difficult to justify the conclusion that where a part of a residential house is used in connection with the business or profession of the owner of that house that portion ceases to be part of the residential house."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning distinguishing own business use from letting out.

key_quotes.text: "The conditions in our country are such which admit of a composite user of the same building. A part of the same house is used for dwelling, and the other part is meant for commercial or business purpose..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains cultural context supporting exemption for composite use (from Firm Ganga Ram).
